#Text=Wikinews interviews Paúl M. Velazco about new yellow-shouldered bat species
#Text=Monday , April 21 , 2014
#Text=Paul Velazco with a Vampyrum spectrum .
#Text=Image : Marco Tschapka .
#Text=Distribution range of species formerly ascribed to Sturnira lilium ( gray tone ) and the type localities ( stars ) of species in the S. lilium complex .
#Text=Image : Paúl M. Velazco .
#Text=Scientists at Chicago 's Field Museum and New York 's American Museum of Natural History have discovered three new species of yellow-shouldered bats , genus Sturnira , in the Neotropics .
#Text=On Wednesday open-access journal ZooKeys published their paper on two of the new species , Sturnira bakeri and Sturnira burtonlimi .
#Text=The two new species were previously confused with S. ludovici , and S. lilium and S. luisi , respectively .
#Text=With the discovery , genus Sturnira now has the most species of any genus in family Phyllostomidae , the leaf-nosed bats .

#Text=Species S. bakeri was named after Dr. Robert J. Baker , who " has made enormous contributions to our [ Authors of the ZooKey paper ] understanding of bats , particularly to the evolution of Neotropical phyllostomids " ; and S. burtonlimi after Dr. Burton K. Lim , who " collected the type series of this species and has made many other important collections throughout the Neotropics and beyond " , the authors noted in the paper .

column1: #Text=Within the New World tropics , the distribution range of the genus , the new species ' known living areas are in Costa Rica and Panama for S. burtonlimi , and Western Ecuador for S. bakeri .
#Text=The researchers identified differences between different specimens , including those in their teeth , skull shapes , and DNA sequences .
#Text=Wikinews interviewed one of the chiropterologists , Paúl M. Velazco of the American Museum of Natural History , about the study .
#Text=The Sturnira genus now has 22 species , over 1.5 times larger than it was a year ago ( 14 species ) .
#Text=Who contributed to this change ?
#Text=Did you participate throughout the entire process , or only the discovery of the last 2 species ?
#Text=The last Mammal Species of the World ( Simmons , 2005 ) recognized 14 species for Sturnira .

#Text=Since then three new species have been described [ S. sorianoi Sánchez-Hernández et al. , 2005 ; S. koopmanhilli McCarthy et al. , 2006 ; and S. perla Jarrín-V . and Kunz , 2011 ] and one subspecies was elevated to the species level ( S. hondurensis ) by Gardner ( 2008 ) .
#Text=This brought the number of species of Sturnira to 18 by 2011 .
#Text=Along with my coauthor Bruce Patterson , we generated the most comprehensive phylogeny of the genus .

#Text=For this we sequenced two nuclear and three mitochondrial genes from the liver or muscle tissue that had been frozen or preserved from each bat specimen , isolating nearly 5,000 base pairs of DNA .
#Text=These sequences were obtained from specimens we have collected in the past ( 38 ) and from tissues we borrowed from different natural history collections .
#Text=We published this phylogeny last year in the journal Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution .
#Text=Results of this study found that two subspecies of Sturnira lilium should be recognized as valid species ( S. parvidens and S. paulsoni ) .
#Text=Additionally we found three new species , two of them described in the ZooKeys paper .
#Text=The third one hopefully will be published later this year .
